preparation_instructions: Slice the okra and set it aside.
Blend the shombo and scotch bonnet peppers.
Wash the beef/chicken and season with salt, seasoning cubes, and onions.
Boil the meat for about 10-15 minutes.
Add stockfish and cook for another 10 minutes.
Introduce palm oil, crayfish, and blended peppers; let it boil for 8 minutes.
Add sliced okra and simmer for an additional 3-4 minutes.
Serve with fufu or eba.
Grind the egusi seeds and set aside in a bowl. Add about a cup of water to make a thick paste.
Parboil the beef with seasoning cubes, salt, and onions for about 10 minutes.
Add water and cook until the meat is tender and the stock is reduced.
Prepare the stockfish by washing it thoroughly to remove sand.
Heat palm oil in a pot for about 2 minutes without bleaching.
Add the egusi paste to the heated oil and stir for 8-10 minutes until crumb-like.
Pour in the cooked meat, add roasted fish, stockfish, ground crayfish, pepper, and water; cover and boil for 10 minutes.
Add washed ugu leaves and dawadawa; taste for salt and pepper.
Allow to simmer for another 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve with eba or pounded yam.
Wash the assorted meat thoroughly and season with salt, sliced onions, and 2 seasoning cubes. Set on heat and allow to cook for about 10-15 minutes.
Add water (1-2 cups) and cook until the meat is tender and the water is almost dried.
Add the smoked fish and stockfish, then add a cup of water and cook for another 10-15 minutes until the stockfish is soft.
In a separate pot, heat palm oil (200 ml) and add sliced onions, ground tatashe, and pepper. Stir and fry for about 10 minutes.
Add the cooked meat, stockfish, and smoked fish to the frying pot. Stir and allow to simmer for another 5 minutes.
Add ground crayfish, iru, and a seasoning cube. Stir well and allow to simmer for an additional 3 minutes.
Finally, add the sliced spinach leaves, stir everything together, and allow to simmer for another 3-5 minutes.
Serve hot with fufu, pounded yam, or any preferred side dish.
Soak the dry fish and stockfish in hot water for a few seconds, then wash and set aside.
Parboil the assorted meat with seasoning cubes, salt, and onions until tender.
Once the meat is cooked and water is reduced, add about 5-7 cups of water.
Add the washed dry fish and stockfish, along with palm oil and ground crayfish. Stir and boil for 10 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to taste, then add another seasoning cube and the ground ogbono seeds. Stir well and cook for an additional five minutes.
Add the fluted pumpkin leaves (or bitter leaves) and stir. Allow to simmer for three minutes.
Serve Ogbono soup with eba, fufu, or semovita.
Boil the bitter leaves in water for 10-15 minutes to reduce bitterness, then wash thoroughly.
Parboil the cow head meat with salt, seasoning cubes, and onions for about 10 minutes, then add water and cook until tender.
Add the washed dry fish and stockfish, then pour in palm oil, ground crayfish, and additional salt and pepper to taste. Allow it to boil.
Incorporate the pounded cocoa yam and ogiri, stirring until the cocoa yam dissolves. If the soup is not thick enough, add a teaspoon of ofor.
Finally, add the washed bitter leaves, stir well, and simmer for an additional 2-3 minutes before serving.
Serve hot with eba, fufu, or any preferred side dish.
Season the chicken or beef with salt, one seasoning cube, half a teaspoon each of curry and thyme, and half a cup of sliced onions. Let it sit for a few minutes.
Set on heat and boil the meat for about 10-15 minutes. Separate the meat and stock into fresh bowls.
Peel and grind the ginger and garlic.
Parboil the rice by boiling about 7 cups of water in a pot, adding the rice, and boiling for 3 minutes. Pour out and wash thoroughly.
Deep-fry the cooked meat and set aside.
In the same pot, reduce oil to 250 ml, add remaining sliced onions, stir for 1-2 minutes, then add ground tomatoes.
Fry the tomatoes for about 20 minutes until they darken and the oil separates.
Add the meat stock to the fried tomatoes along with ginger/garlic, curry, thyme, salt to taste, and water. Stir well.
Add the parboiled rice to the pot, cover, and cook on low heat for 30-45 minutes. Add water occasionally if needed.
Serve hot with fried meat, salad, or your favorite drink.
Parboil the chicken and liver with spices (salt, sliced onions, thyme, curry, seasoning cubes, ginger, and garlic) for about 10-15 minutes. Reserve the stock.
Chop the cabbage, green beans, carrots, and liver, and set aside.
Parboil the rice with half of the meat stock and two cups of water until about 70% done.
In a pot, heat vegetable oil (200 ml) and sauté sliced onions for 1-2 minutes.
Add chopped carrots and green beans, followed by chopped liver and sweet corn. Stir well.
Pour in the meat stock, add ground pepper (if desired), salt, and seasoning cube. Stir and taste for seasoning.
Add green peas, stir for another minute, then add cabbage and curry powder. Mix until well combined.
Finally, add the almost-done rice to the pot, stir everything together, cover, and allow to simmer for about 5-7 minutes.
Serve hot with fried or grilled chicken.
Transfer the beans into a clean bowl, sprinkle half a cup of water, and start squeezing hard against your palm to remove the outer coat.
Continue rubbing against your palm, adding more water as necessary, until the beans are fully de-coated (about 10 minutes).
Soak the beans in water for about 45 minutes.
Blend the peeled beans with the shombo or tatashe, using very little water to avoid a watery mixture.
Allow the blended mixture to sit in a bowl for about 1 hour to help it swell and bond better.
Smoothen the mixture further using a mortar and pestle or pulse in a blender for a few seconds.
Heat the vegetable oil in a pot for frying. Scoop in the batter and fry until golden brown, flipping as necessary.
Drain excess oil on a sieve and serve hot, often paired with pap or custard.
Start by parboiling the rice and beans separately, wash them, and set aside in different bowls.
Grind the fresh tomatoes and scotch bonnet peppers together.
Parboil the chicken with seasoning cubes, half a cup of sliced onions, and salt for about 10-15 minutes. Reserve the chicken stock.
Fry or grill the chicken and set aside.
Transfer the parboiled beans into a cooking pot with water and sliced onions, boiling for about 30-40 minutes until almost done.
In another pot, heat vegetable oil and sauté half a cup of sliced onions for a minute before adding the ground tomato mixture and canned tomatoes.
Stir and fry until the mixture thickens and loses its sour taste (about 15-20 minutes). Remove half of the mixture and set aside.
Add the reserved chicken stock, two cups of water, one seasoning cube, salt to taste, and a teaspoon each of curry, ginger, and garlic powder. Stir to combine.
Taste for salt, then add the pre-cooked beans and parboiled rice. Stir well.
Add the remaining fried tomato mixture on top of the rice and beans, spreading it evenly. Add the remaining sliced onions.
Cover and cook on medium heat for about 25 to 40 minutes until the rice and beans are soft and water is absorbed.
Use a wooden spoon to gently stir everything together before serving with fried chicken or your choice of sides.
Slice half of the red onion and combine the remaining half with the white onions, pepper, and a cup of water, then blend until smooth.
Set your cooking pot on heat, add the palm oil, and allow it to heat for about 3 minutes without bleaching.
Once the oil is heated, add the sliced red onions and fry for about 3 minutes.
Add the blended pepper and onion mixture to the pot and fry for the next 15-25 minutes until the sauce darkens and thickens.
Add a seasoning cube and salt to taste, then fry for another 3-4 minutes until done.
For the beans, boil them in water with a pinch of salt until they are really soft.
Serve the ewa agoyin sauce with the cooked beans and agege bread or any preferred bread.
Wash the catfish thoroughly with hot water to remove the slimy outer layer.
Slice the onions, utazi leaves, and prepare other ingredients.
Transfer the washed catfish into a pot, adding enough water to submerge it.
Add a seasoning cube, salt, and the ground crayfish and pepper.
Allow boiling for about 10-15 minutes before adding lion pepper soup spice and kitchen glory.
Add the sliced utazi and scent leaves, then cover to cook for another 7-10 minutes.
Taste for salt and adjust as needed.
Serve the pepper soup hot with boiled yam.
Peel the yam, slice it into serveable sizes, wash, and set aside.
Blend the tomatoes, fresh pepper, and half a cup of crayfish.
In a cooking pot, heat the palm oil for about two minutes and add half of the sliced onions.
Pour in the blended tomatoes and peppers, frying for five to ten minutes.
Add enough water to submerge the yam pieces and bring to a boil.
Add the sliced yams, crayfish, seasoning cube, and salt. Cook for ten minutes.
Add the remaining sliced onions and cover to cook for another five minutes.
Check if the yam is soft by piercing with a fork. Stir until it thickens.
Serve hot, optionally adding vegetables for extra flavor.
Boil water in a large pot, add salt, and cook the spaghetti according to package instructions until al dente. Drain and set aside.
In a separate pot, heat vegetable oil over medium heat and sauté sliced onions until translucent.
Add the ground beef or minced meat, stirring until browned.
Pour in the blended tomatoes and let it cook for about 10 minutes until the sauce thickens.
Add sliced bell pepper and carrots, followed by seasoning cubes and salt. Stir well and cook for an additional 5 minutes.
Combine the cooked spaghetti with the sauce, mixing thoroughly to coat the spaghetti evenly.
Allow to simmer for an additional 2-3 minutes to meld flavors.
Serve hot, garnished with additional bell peppers or fresh herbs if desired.
Break the Indomie noodles into a bowl and pour boiled water over them, allowing them to soften for about 5 minutes.
In a frying pan, heat vegetable oil and add sliced tomatoes, onions, and fresh pepper. Fry for about 5 minutes.
Drain the water from the noodles after about 4 minutes and add the seasoning spices while the noodles are still hot.
Crack the eggs into the bowl with the noodles and stir well.
Transfer the noodle mixture to the frying pan with the fried tomatoes and onions. Cook and stir for about 5 minutes until fully combined.
Serve hot, optionally with a cold drink.
Slice the tomatoes, onions, and peppers.
Heat the vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat.
Add the sliced onions, tomatoes, and peppers to the pan. Fry for about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
Add salt to taste and half of the seasoning cube. Stir well.
In a separate bowl, beat the eggs with a pinch of salt.
Pour the beaten eggs into the frying pan over the tomato mixture. Allow it to cook for a minute before stirring gently to break it into smaller pieces.
If desired, sprinkle in sliced green peppers and stir further.
Serve hot with boiled yam or your choice of side.
Peel the yam and slice it into desired shapes. Boil for about 15 minutes until soft. Drain and allow to cool.
In a bowl, mix the ground ginger, garlic, pepper, salt, and seasoning cube with the three eggs. Whisk until well combined.
Heat the vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat.
Immerse the boiled yam slices in the egg mixture, ensuring they are well coated.
Carefully drop the coated yam into the hot oil and fry until golden brown, flipping as necessary.
Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels to absorb excess oil.
Serve hot with your favorite sauce or accompaniment such as tomato stew or grilled fish.
Dice the carrot, onion, red bell pepper, green bell pepper, ginger, and garlic separately.
Boil the spaghetti in a pot with a spoonful of oil until it is about 70% to 80% done (approximately 10-15 minutes). Drain and set aside.
In a frying pan, heat the vegetable oil and add the diced onions and carrots. Cook for about 2-3 minutes over medium heat.
Add the diced green and red bell peppers, cooking for another 3-4 minutes.
Stir in the chopped ginger, garlic, thyme, seasoning cubes, curry powder, and salt to taste. Mix well.
Add the parboiled spaghetti to the stir-fried vegetables and cook for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve hot as a delicious meal for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.
Wash the beans thoroughly to remove the outer coat by squeezing with your hands and rinsing until only the white beans remain.
Split the tatashe or shombo peppers in half, remove seeds, and wash.
Parboil the mackerel, remove bones, and break into smaller pieces.
In a blender, combine the washed beans, onions, crayfish, and tatashe or shombo. Blend until smooth.
Transfer the blended mixture into a large bowl and add vegetable oil, seasoning cubes, fish stock, and salt. Stir well to combine.
Distribute the mixture into plates or moi moi wrappers. Optionally, place a cooked egg in the center of each portion.
Place the filled plates in a pot, adding water carefully to avoid overflowing into the plates. Cover tightly.
Cook for about 40 to 60 minutes, checking occasionally to ensure there is enough water in the pot.
After cooking, allow to cool for about 30-60 minutes before serving with pap (akamu), rice, or custard.
Peel off the yam, slice it to your desired size, and deep-fry. Add a little salt before frying.
In a frying pan or cooking pot, heat about 20 cl of groundnut or vegetable oil.
Pour in the chopped or blended tomatoes and fresh pepper. Fry for about 10 minutes.
Add the sliced onions and continue to fry for another 10 to 15 minutes, stirring occasionally until the sauce loses its sour taste.
Add a seasoning cube and salt to taste. Optionally, you can add fluted pumpkin.
Serve the tomato sauce with fried yam, potatoes, plantains, or rice.
Start by seasoning the chicken with salt, smoked paprika, garlic powder, and any other desired spices.
Place a large skillet on high heat and add coconut oil.
Add the seasoned chicken pieces and sear on all sides until browned.
Stir in the minced onions, tomatoes, and peppers, cooking for a few minutes until softened.
Add the coconut milk and rice to the skillet. Season with additional salt and spices as needed.
Add the bay leaf, cover, and simmer until the rice is cooked through and has absorbed the coconut milk.

ingredients.name: Beans (black-eyed peas or any preferred type)

preparation_instructions: Wash the beans thoroughly and boil in a pot with water until soft (about 30 minutes). Drain and set aside.
In another pot, boil water and add the white rice. Cook until tender, then drain and set aside.
In a frying pan, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add sliced onions and sauté until translucent.
Add the blended tomatoes to the pan and cook for about 10-15 minutes until the sauce thickens.
Stir in the cooked beans, seasoning cubes, salt, and ground pepper. Mix well and let it simmer for another 5-10 minutes.
Serve the white rice topped with the beans and tomato stew.

ingredients.name: Cayenne pepper or crushed red pepper flakes

preparation_instructions: Slice the onions and scotch bonnet peppers, and set aside.
In a deep pot, heat the palm oil on medium heat. Sauté one sliced onion for about 10 minutes until caramelized.
Add the cooked snails and clams to the pot, sautéing for another 5 minutes.
Incorporate the braised goat meat along with its reserved braising liquid.
Add chicken bouillon, crayfish, and cayenne pepper if desired. Stir in the chopped water leaf.
Once the water leaf starts to wilt, add the Afang leaves and stir well.
Pour in about 1 cup of the braising liquid, reduce heat to low, and cover. Cook for another 10 minutes.
Taste for seasoning and adjust salt if necessary. Allow to sit for 5 minutes before serving hot.
Season the assorted meat with salt, two seasoning cubes, and sliced onions. Cook for about 10 minutes, then add water and cook until the meat is about 70% tender.
Wash the dried fish and stockfish with hot water to remove sand and impurities, then add them to the cooking meat.
Once the meat is tender, add palm oil and allow it to cook for another 5-10 minutes until well combined.
Add salt and pepper to taste, ensuring the mixture is boiling with very little water remaining.
Stir in the water leaves and allow to cook for about 3 minutes before adding the fluted pumpkin leaves (ugwu).
Add the ground crayfish, periwinkles (if using), and one seasoning cube. Stir well.
Sprinkle in the ofor or achi to thicken the soup, cover halfway, and simmer for an additional 3-5 minutes.
Serve hot with Nigerian fufu, semo, wheat, eba, or pounded yam.

ingredients.name: Long-grain white rice or basmati rice

preparation_instructions: In a large pan over medium heat, cook the ground beef, sausage, and chicken livers until browned. Season with salt and black pepper.
Add flour and stir. Incorporate the diced onion, celery, and green bell pepper, sautéing for about 2 minutes.
Stir in the minced garlic, Cajun seasoning, cayenne pepper, oregano, thyme, and bay leaves. Mix well.
Add rice and chicken broth to the mixture. Bring to a boil, cover, reduce heat to low, and simmer for about 20 minutes.
Remove from heat and allow to rest for 5 minutes. Fluff the rice with a fork before serving.
Garnish with chopped green onions and parsley before serving.
